[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: I think tipping culture has gotten out of hand. I shouldn’t feel obligated to tip if I’m not having my food delivered to my table. I would like to see a minimum tip added on to a meal receipt above a certain amount.

displayed_text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Summary of Comments on Tipping System

The comments reveal strong dissatisfaction with the current tipping system, with many participants expressing frustration about its expansion beyond traditional service contexts. A significant portion of respondents feel that tipping has become excessive and intrusive, particularly with digital payment systems that prompt for tips in situations where they were not previously expected, such as takeout orders or minimal service transactions.

Key Concerns Raised

Tipping Expansion and Pressure: Many participants noted that tipping requests have spread to inappropriate contexts, with some feeling "bullied" or pressured into tipping. The prevalence of digital payment terminals that default to tipping options was frequently cited as making it uncomfortable to decline.

Wage Structure Issues: A recurring theme throughout the comments is that employers should pay livable wages rather than relying on customers to supplement worker income through tips. Participants recognize that many service workers depend heavily on tips due to low base wages, creating an unfair system for both workers and customers.

Mandatory vs. Voluntary: There's widespread agreement that tipping should be voluntary and based on service quality, not an obligation. Several participants mentioned that other countries handle this better by incorporating service costs into prices and paying workers fairly.

Proposed Solutions

The most common suggestion is to eliminate tipping entirely and require employers to pay fair, livable wages. Other proposals include:

  • Making "no tip" options more accessible on payment systems
  • Implementing a standard service charge (such as 10%) instead of variable tipping
  • Restricting tip requests to situations involving actual service
  • Returning to a system where tips are genuinely optional rewards for exceptional service

While a minority of participants support tipping as a way to reward good service or help workers earn more, the overwhelming sentiment favors significant reform or elimination of the current tipping system in favor of fair base wages and truly optional gratuity.

Summary B

Summary of Comments on the Tipping System

The comments reveal significant dissatisfaction with the current tipping system, with many participants expressing frustration about its expansion beyond traditional service contexts. A recurring theme is the feeling of being pressured or "bullied" into tipping, particularly with digital payment systems that make it uncomfortable to decline. Many note that tipping requests now appear in situations where no actual service is provided, such as picking up takeout orders.

Key Concerns About Current System

A substantial portion of respondents feel that tipping has become "out of control" and "over-expected" in the United States. They express frustration with: - Point-of-sale systems that default to high tip percentages - Being asked to tip before receiving service - The expansion of tipping to non-service transactions - The awkwardness of declining to tip in face-to-face interactions

Proposed Solutions

The most common suggestion is to eliminate tipping entirely and ensure workers receive livable base wages. Many participants point to European models where service charges are incorporated into prices. Specific recommendations include:

  • Paying service workers minimum wage or higher so they don't rely on tips
  • Making tipping purely optional for exceptional service
  • Implementing a standard service charge (such as 10%) instead of variable tipping
  • Redesigning payment systems to make "no tip" options more accessible
  • Restricting tip requests to situations involving actual service
Perspectives on Tipping Practice

While most comments are critical of the system, some participants maintain positive views about tipping when it's voluntary and merit-based. These individuals: - Always tip at restaurants and for delivery services - Believe in rewarding good service - Recognize that workers currently depend on tips due to low base wages - View tipping as a way to show appreciation for hard work

Overall, the comments suggest strong support for reforming the tipping system, with most favoring either its elimination or significant restructuring to reduce pressure on consumers while ensuring fair compensation for workers.
